Award.AwardTitle: Phenomenological Studies of Cool-Season Extreme Weather Events over Central and Eastern North America on Intraseasonal Time Scales
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to investigate extreme weather events (EWEs), defined here as a category of high-impact weather events that are societally disruptive, geographically widespread, exceptionally prolonged, and climatologically infrequent, from a phenomenological perspective. It is hypothesized that planetary-scale wave amplification and breaking are necessary for the occurrence of EWEs, because the resulting high-amplitude flow patterns may lead to intense cyclogenesis and anticyclogenesis, and subsequently to downstream ridge amplification and blocking, that can modulate the positions of storm tracks and atmospheric rivers and establish synoptic-scale environments favorable for the occurrence of EWEs.

The proposed research extends the ongoing NSF-supported investigation by the PI and Co-PI of high-impact weather events occurring over the eastern North Pacific and North America that are linked dynamically to western North Pacific tropical cyclones (TCs) through Rossby wave dispersion along the North Pacific jet stream (NPJ) by: (i) narrowing the focus on high-impact weather events occurring over the eastern North Pacific and North America to noteworthy cool-season EWEs occurring over central and eastern North America since 1979, and (ii) broadening the dynamical linkages between TCs and high-impact weather events to include antecedent disturbances of tropical, midlatitude, and polar origin that modulate the evolution of the NPJ on 10-20 day time scales prior to and during the occurrence of the class of EWEs specified in (i). The proposed extensions will be accomplished by: (i) determining the role of planetary-scale wave amplification and breaking in the subsequent occurrence of the aforementioned class of EWEs; (ii) investigating how cyclogenesis and anticyclogenesis, and subsequent downstream ridge amplification and blocking, establish synoptic-scale environments conducive to the occurrence of the aforementioned class of EWEs. These goals will be addressed by conducting multiscale investigations of EWEs using state-of-the-art global gridded reanalyses and, in conjunction with these multiscale investigations, identifying factors limiting predictability through the synoptic evaluation of the skill of several operational global models, including ensemble forecast products, for selected "hard-to-predict" cool-season EWEs occurring over central and eastern North America.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of this NSF-funded research project was on extreme weather events (EWEs), defined here as a category of high-impact weather events that are societally disruptive, geographically widespread, exceptionally prolonged, and climatologically infrequent, from a phenomenological perspective. We hypothesized that the Northern Hemisphere jet stream is especially ?wavy? prior to and during the occurrence of EWEs.  A wavy jet stream enables warm, moist air masses from the tropics and subtropics to reach middle and higher latitudes, while cold, dry air masses from higher latitudes are able to reach lower latitudes. These air mass exchanges between lower, middle, and higher latitudes are especially conducive to frequent storminess along weather-front boundaries that separate the different air masses characteristic of these respective latitudes.  These air mass exchanges may also be associated with a variety of EWEs that can include continental and regional cold waves and heat waves, as well as strong extratropical cyclones capable of producing widespread damaging winds, flooding, heavy snow and blizzard conditions, and severe convective storms. A special category of EWEs occurs when the wavy jet stream results in the formation of a high-latitude blocking anticyclone in the middle and upper troposphere.  Blocking anticyclones are so named because the rhythmic weather changes that characterize middle latitudes cease and the weather you have now may be the weather you will have for the next several weeks. Blocking episodes can persist for one to two weeks (or longer) and are often associated with prolonged spells of cold, hot, dry, or wet weather that can stress daily human life (e.g., heat-wave-induced illnesses and deaths), interrupt electricity distribution (e.g., outages due to excessive demand), and disrupt transportation (e.g., widespread flight delays and cancellations).

Research supported by this NSF grant has focused on noteworthy cool-season EWEs that occur over central and eastern North America in association with widespread heavy rainfall and extensive flooding and with strong extratropical cyclones.  We showed that a wavy jet stream over the western and central North Pacific can arise from the interaction of western Pacific hurricanes recurving into middle latitudes in conjunction with polar air masses moving southeastward off the Asian continent.  We also showed that this weather scenario may be favorable for the development of high-latitude atmospheric blocking across Alaska and northwestern North America, with the subsequent occurrence of EWEs over the continental United States and the western North Atlantic Ocean. We further showed that extratropical cyclones leading to EWEs over central and eastern North America differ from ordinary extratropical cyclones with respect to the magnitude, areal extent, and duration of strong winds near the surface.  We constructed a climatology of extratropical cyclones leading to EWEs over central and eastern North America and demonstrated that these cyclones typically form in the lee of the Rocky Mountains, over the south-central United States, and along the east coast of North America. We also showed that extratropical cyclones leading to EWEs are associated with an equatorward-shifted jet stream and, on an annual basis, form most frequently in November and March.

We also investigated extreme precipitation events (EPEs) over the central and eastern United States. We focused on widespread EPEs that are associated with exceptionally large rainfall totals. We found that these EPEs are associated with ?wave breaking? (analogous to waves approaching a beach) that facilitates the transport of very moist air masses poleward ahead of frontal boundaries. Once again, we found that the wavier the jet stream is across North America the greater is the likelihood that warm, moist air can be drawn poleward from the tropics and subtropics into the central and eastern United States. Once this warm, moist air is in place over the United States east of the Rockies it is able to serve as a focus for heavy precipitation, where the air is lifted ahead of eastward-advancing weather disturbances and their associated cold fronts accompanying mobile extratropical cyclones.
